messageBody:
On Tue, 26 Nov 2002, Alain Ravet wrote:
> Erik Hanson wrote:
> > IDEA 3.0 was released last week or the week before, and ...
> > Unfortunatley, the price has gone up a lot too.
> > It's $500, or $700 if you want free upgrades for a year,
> > up from $400 with free upgrades for 8 months.)
>
> Good news : you're wrong.

I hope so!


> it's still
> - $399 for the full version, or
> - $199 for the upgrade,
> with "basic maintenance and support". (=> includes free bugfixes for
> 3.0, no time limit, and access to the EAP)
> More details here
> http://www.intellij.com/idea/buy.jsp
>
> Many people - like me, and you - were initially mislead by the new
> wording of the license scheme. The annual maintenance and support is
> targeted at companies who want/need more/faster support.
>
> With the "basic maintenance and support", you still have access to the
> support forums, and the EAP (Early Access Program). It is still
> running, and has already produced 2 bugfixes releases, that work with
> the standard licenses.
> It should also give you access to next EAP (for the next version), that,
> I think, should start in about 2 months.

I was ignoring the "special pricing" because it expires at the end of the
year. So that's why I said $500 vs. the $400 you quoted. But let's assume
that we buy during the special pricing phase and that they always offer a
special price when they release a new version and that they release one or
two more versions in the 12-month period starting now.


So if you were a new owner, you'd pay $399 without the contract. If
IntelliJ released one new version during the year, you'd also pay a $199
upgrade price, for a total of $598. If they released two versions during
the year, you'd pay an extra $199, for a total of $797.

However, if you got the contract, you'd pay $599. If they released one
version during the year, you'd still have paid $599. And if they released
two versions during the year, you'd still have paid $599 (a savings of
$198).


It's similar for current onwers of version 2.6: upgrade without the
support contract for $199, upgrade again for $199 ($398 total), perhaps
upgrade again for $199 ($597 total). Upgrade with the support contract for
$399 and don't pay extra if they release one or two versions during the
year.


So the only way the non-support contract way is better is if IntelliJ
didn't release any new versions during the year. Or if they did but
charged less for them than they are charging for the 2.6 -> 3.0 upgrade.

Unless I'm missing something (which I hope I am). (Though I wasn't
complaining about the price; it's worth it to my company.)


Erik
